title: SpaNorm: Spatially aware library size normalisation
text: SpaNorm spatially aware library size normalisation method removes library size effects, retaining biology. Library sizes need removed molecular datasets allow comparisons across observations, case, across space. Bhuva et al. (Bhuva et al. 2024) Atta et al. (Atta et al. 2024) shown standard single-cell inspired library size normalisation approaches appropriate spatial molecular datasets often remove biological signals . library size confounds biology spatial molecular data. SpaNorm uses unique approach spatially constraint modelling approach model gene expression (e.g., counts) remove library size effects, retaining biology. achieves three key innovations: Optmial decomposition spatial variation spatially smooth library size associated (technical) library size independent (biology) variation using generalized linear models (GLMs). Computing spatially smooth functions (using thin plate splines) represent gene- location-/cell-/spot- specific size factors. Adjustment data using percentile adjusted counts (PAC) (Salim et al. 2022), well adjustment approaches (e.g., Pearson). SpaNorm package can installed follows:
code: if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager")  # release version BiocManager::install("SpaNorm") # development version from GitHub BiocManager::install("bhuvad/SpaNorm")

title: SpaNorm: Spatially aware library size normalisation
text: begin loading example 10x Visium data profiling dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) human brain. data ~4,000 spots covers genome-wide measurements. example data filtered remove lowly expressed genes (using filterGenes(HumanDLPFC, prop = 0.1)). filtering retains genes expressed least 10% cells.  filterGenes function returns logical vector indicating genes kept. log-transformed raw counts visualised gene MOBP marker oligodendrocytes enriched white matter (WM) (Maynard et al. 2021). Despite marker region, see fact absent white matter region.
code: library(SpaNorm) library(SpatialExperiment) library(ggplot2)  # load sample data data(HumanDLPFC) # change gene IDs to gene names rownames(HumanDLPFC) = rowData(HumanDLPFC)$gene_name HumanDLPFC #> class: SpatialExperiment  #> dim: 5076 4015  #> metadata(0): #> assays(1): counts #> rownames(5076): NOC2L HES4 ... MT-CYB AC007325.4 #> rowData names(2): gene_name gene_biotype #> colnames(4015): AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 ... #>   TTGTTTCCATACAACT-1 TTGTTTGTGTAAATTC-1 #> colData names(3): cell_count sample_id AnnotatedCluster #> reducedDimNames(0): #> mainExpName: NULL #> altExpNames(0): #> spatialCoords names(2) : pxl_col_in_fullres pxl_row_in_fullres #> imgData names(4): sample_id image_id data scaleFactor  # plot regions p_region = plotSpatial(HumanDLPFC, colour = AnnotatedCluster, size = 0.5) +   scale_colour_brewer(palette = "Paired", guide = guide_legend(override.aes = list(shape = 15, size = 5))) +   ggtitle("Region") p_region # filter genes expressed in 20% of spots keep = filterGenes(HumanDLPFC, 0.2) table(keep) #> keep #> FALSE  TRUE  #>  2568  2508 # subset genes HumanDLPFC = HumanDLPFC[keep, ] logcounts(HumanDLPFC) = log2(counts(HumanDLPFC) + 1)  p_counts = plotSpatial(     HumanDLPFC,     colour = MOBP,     what = "expression",     assay = "logcounts",     size = 0.5   ) +   scale_colour_viridis_c(option = "F") +   ggtitle("logCounts") p_region + p_counts

title: SpaNorm: Spatially aware library size normalisation
text: SpaNorm normalises data two steps: (1) fitting SpaNorm model library sizes; (2) adjusting data using fit model. single call SpaNorm() function enough run two steps. speed computation, model fit using smaller proportion spots/cells (default 0.25). can modified using sample.p parameter. output (can switched setting verbose = FALSE), shows two steps normalisation. model fitting step, 1004 cells/spots used fit negative binomial (NB) model. Subsequent output shows fit performed alternating estimation dispersion parameter estimation NB parameters fixing dispersion. output also shows intermediate fit converges, final fit. accuracy fit can controlled modifying tolerance parameter tol (default 1e-4). Next, data adjusted using fit model. following approaches implemented count data: adj.method = "logpac" (default) - percentile adjusted counts (PAC) estimates count gene location/spot/cell using model contain unwanted effects library size. adj.method = "person" - Pearson residuals factoring unwanted effects. adj.method = "meanbio" - mean gene location estimated biological component model. adj.method = "medbio" - median gene location estimated biological component model. data stored logcounts assay SpatialExperiment object. normalisation, see MOBP enriched white matter.

MT-ND6 MT-CYB #> rowData names(2): gene_name gene_biotype #> colnames(4015): AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 ... #>   TTGTTTCCATACAACT-1 TTGTTTGTGTAAATTC-1 #> colData names(3): cell_count sample_id AnnotatedCluster #> reducedDimNames(0): #> mainExpName: NULL #> altExpNames(0): #> spatialCoords names(2) : pxl_col_in_fullres pxl_row_in_fullres #> imgData names(4): sample_id image_id data scaleFactor p_logpac = plotSpatial(     HumanDLPFC,     colour = MOBP,     what = "expression",     assay = "logcounts",     size = 0.5   ) +   scale_colour_viridis_c(option = "F") +   ggtitle("logPAC") p_region + p_logpac

what: Spatially-aware normalisation for spatial transcriptomics data
title: Spatially-aware normalisation for spatial transcriptomics data
text: SpaNorm spatially aware library size normalisation method removes library size effects, retaining biology. Library sizes need removed molecular datasets allow comparisons across observations, case, across space. Bhuva et al. (2024) Atta et al. (2023) shown standard single-cell inspired library size normalisation approaches appropriate spatial molecular datasets often remove biological signals . library size confounds biology spatial molecular data. SpaNorm uses unique approach spatially constraint modelling approach model gene expression (e.g., counts) remove library size effects, retaining biology. achieves three key innovations: Computing spatially smooth functions (using thin plate splines) represent gene- location-/cell-/spot- specific size factors. Optimal decomposition spatial variation spatially smooth library size associated (technical) library size independent (biology) variation using generalized linear models (GLMs). Adjustment data using percentile adjusted counts (PAC) (Salim et al., 2022), well adjustment approaches (e.g., Pearson).

title: Spatially-dependent normalisation for spatial transcriptomics data — SpaNorm
text: SpaNorm works first fitting spatial regression model library size data. Normalised data can computed using various adjustment approaches. negative binomial gene-model used, data can adjusted using following approaches: 'logpac', 'pearson', 'medbio', 'meanbio'. Batch effects can specified using batch parameter. parameter vector, design matrix created within function using model.matrix. custom design provided form numeric matrix, ideally created using model.matrix. batch matrix created intercept term. SpaNorm function automatically detect intercept term remove relevant column. Alternatively, users can subset model matrix remove column manually. Please note model formula include intercept term intercept column subset .
